dialogue: Look at these two bars. Both have two pieces shaded. Which fraction is larger?

workspace.description: Bar divided into fourths with 2 pieces shaded
Bar divided into sixths with 2 pieces shaded

correct_answer.context: 2/4 is greater than 2/6 because fourths are bigger pieces than sixths, even though the same number of pieces are shaded

success_path_dialogue: Right. Same count, but bigger pieces win.

steps.dialogue: Not quite. Look at the size of the shaded pieces in each bar.
Let's think about this together. Both bars have 2 pieces shaded, but that doesn't mean they're equal. Compare the size of one fourth to the size of one sixth. Which pieces are bigger?

Let me walk you through this. Yes, both bars have 2 pieces shaded. But look closely at the size of those pieces. The first bar is divided into fourths - that means 4 equal parts make the whole. The second bar is divided into sixths - 6 equal parts make the whole. When you divide something into more pieces, each piece gets smaller. So one fourth is bigger than one sixth. That means 2 fourths is bigger than 2 sixths. The answer is 2/4 > 2/6. When fractions have the same numerator, the one with the smaller denominator is larger because its pieces are bigger.
